title: Ask HN: How do you go about evaluating interns at the end of their contract?
text: What are some effective ways of evaluating interns at the end of their contract? I ask because we do not measure interns based on normal impact metrics as an employee. Interns are here to learn–and in turn help us learn by teaching–not affect our bottom line. So what are some good quantifiable ways to determine if they're a good fit to convert to a job offer?

Expiration date on exercising options – total BS?
text: I don't understand why there is an expiration date on exercising stock option grants.  Anyone have a compelling reason why this even exists?  Seems to force stock option holders to 1) Make decisions when they aren't necessarily ready to and 2) Take on tax burdens before they ever see a payout.

Ask HN: How many people switch besties every 2 years?
text:
I'm one of those people who switch besties every 2 years.

My latest just broke up with me when they realized I don't consider them a bestie (but they did consider me a bestie).

My longest bestie-ship: 2 years. The shortest: 1 semester.

Please define BESTIE however makes sense to you. I consider a BESTIE to be whoever I think about the most when I don't think about myself (FYI I have no biological children).

I'm being deliberately vague so I can get a wide variety of responses.

title: RT60 Calculator
How to Own Your Growth as a Software Engineer
text:
I was reflecting on my career journey recently and decided to put down some thoughts on what I found to be vital to my growth in case if you find it helpful.

It took shape as this blog post where I cover four tenets to owning your growth:

- Do the job that's needed of you

- Understand where you are on your career journey

- Advocate for yourself through storytelling

- Learn to organize your thoughts & communicate articulately

Does any of that resonate with you? What advice has been pivotal to your growth? Please share it in the comments!

https://build.betterup.com/how-to-own-your-growth-as-a-software-engineer/
